subject: Ethics
title: Deforestation Moral Costs
description: A 60-second lesson on Deforestation Moral Costs.

hook.text: Brazil lost 10,000 square kilometers of Amazon rainforest in one year. That's half of New Jerseyâ€”gone.

buildup.text: Forests store carbon, produce oxygen, and shelter 80% of land-based species. They also house Indigenous peoples.

discovery.text: Deforestation isn't just an environmental lossâ€”it displaces communities and destroys irreplaceable ecosystems.

twist.text: But farmers clearing land are often desperately poor. Telling them to stop means telling them to starve.

climax.text: The moral burden falls on wealthy nations whose demand for beef and soy drives the destruction.

punchline.text: Your hamburger has a hidden cost: someone's forest.

quiz.question: Why is deforestation an ethical issue beyond environmentalism?
options: It only affects trees and has no human impact
It displaces communities, destroys ecosystems, and is driven by wealthy nations' demand
Deforestation is always done by large corporations, never small farmers
